title: 113_hr1917
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States-Cuba Normalization Act of 2013". Congress finds that Cuba is no longer a threat to the United States or the Western Hemisphere after the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union. The continuation of the trade embargo declared in 1962 is not fulfilling its purpose. The US is engaging with other countries like China and Vietnam to promote democratic and human rights reforms. Normal trade relations with Cuba would help its economy develop based on free market principles. The United States can support democratic change and human rights in Cuba by promoting trade, travel, communications, and cultural exchanges. Expanding bilateral trade relations can further progress in Cuba on human rights and democratic rule. Cuba's membership in international trade organizations warrants unconditional normal trade relations treatment from the US. SEC. 3. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA. The text chunk discusses the repeal of certain authorities related to trade with Cuba, including the removal of export prohibitions under the Export Administration Act of 1979. The Act under the Export Administration Act of 1979 related to trade with Cuba will cease to be effective. The President can impose new export controls and exercise authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in response to a national emergency threat from Cuba. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, citing an unusual threat to national security, foreign policy, or the economy of the United States. Conforming amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing certain paragraphs and sections from various acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing specific sections related to Cuba and redesignating certain paragraphs within the act. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing sections related to Cuba and redesignating certain paragraphs within the act. This includes repealing the prohibition on transactions or payments with respect to certain United States intellectual property and terminating the denial of foreign tax credit with respect to Cuba. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended to remove sections related to Cuba, including repealing the prohibition on transactions with certain United States intellectual property and terminating the denial of foreign tax credit. Additionally, the Code of 1986 is amended to exempt Cuba from certain provisions after 60 days from the enactment date. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. SEC. 5 allows travel to and from Cuba for US citizens without regulation. Transactions related to travel, such as banking involving foreign currency, are also permitted. The United States Postal Service will establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, using charter providers if necessary. The President is urged to negotiate with Cuba to settle U.S. nationals' property claims and protect human rights. SEC. 8. EXTENSION OF NONDISCRIMINATORY TRADE TREATMENT. The Congress supports promoting democratic change and economic reform in Cuba by normalizing trade relations. Upon enactment of this Act, the US will no longer need to use article XXI of the GATT 1994 with respect to Cuba. The President retains authority to invoke article XXI of the GATT 1994 in the future. The Uruguay Round Agreements Act is amended to extend nondiscriminatory treatment to Cuban products by repealing certain tariff classification acts and terminating the application of trade acts to Cuba. The Trade Act of 1974 will no longer apply to Cuba, and the Uruguay Round Agreements Act will extend nondiscriminatory treatment to Cuban products. The President must report to Congress on trade relations between the US and Cuba within 18 months of this Act's enactment. SEC. 9 prohibits limiting annual remittances to Cuba by individuals under US jurisdiction, with exceptions for money laundering offenses. SEC. 10 involves removing Cuba from the state sponsors of terrorism list. SEC. 10 removes Cuba from the state sponsors of terrorism list, rescinding any previous determination by the Secretary of State. This section references specific provisions of law and takes effect upon enactment. Congress acknowledges that the Government of Cuba has signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and recognizes the United Nations Human Rights Council's condemnation of the arbitrary detention of Alan Phillip Gross. The United States policy is to demand Gross's immediate release and ensure he receives necessary medical treatment. SEC. 12. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after the enactment date or 60 days after President certifies Alan Phillip Gross's release from Cuban custody, whichever is later.
